poem:
### Unwanted Guests

In the quiet night,  
whispers scurry through walls,  
uninvited companions.

Trap and poison,  
arms of war  
against the fragile claim of comfort.

Yet still, persistent  
rattlings of tiny feet,  
a testament to resilience.

We share space  
with all things small,  
a lesson in patience  
wrapped in fur and wings.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The experts: Pest controllers on 17 simple, lasting ways to get rid of unwanted house guests With reported rises in the number of rats and bedbugs, it is likely that many of us are sharing our living space with some pest or other. How can you go about getting rid of them? And what can you do to avoid them moving in to start with? Here, pest controllers share the secrets to an infestation-free life.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: The experts: Pest controllers on 17 simple, lasting ways to get rid of unwanted house guests With reported rises in the number of rats and bedbugs, it is likely that many of us are sharing our living space with some pest or other. How can you go about getting rid of them? And what can you do to avoid them moving in to start with? Here, pest controllers share the secrets to an infestation-free life.
